class=\"big-branded\">\n\n    <div class=\"publication-name\" id=\"wd-pub-name\">\n\t<div class=\"publication-title\" itemprop=\"name\" itemid=\"periodical\">\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Journal image link tile    <div class=\"partner-logo-alignment\">\n                <!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The American Astronomical Society (AAS), established in 1899 and based in Washington, DC, is the major organization of professional astronomers in North America. Its membership of about 7,000 individuals also includes physicists, mathematicians, geologists, engineers, and others whose research and educational interests lie within the broad spectrum of subjects comprising contemporary astronomy. The mission of the AAS is to enhance and share humanity's scientific understanding of the universe.</p> <p><a href=\"https://aas.org/\">https://aas.org/</a></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The Institute of Physics (IOP) is a leading scientific society promoting physics and bringing physicists together for the benefit of all. It has a worldwide membership of around 50 000 comprising physicists from all sectors, as well as those with an interest in physics. It works to advance physics research, application and education; and engages with policy makers and the public to develop awareness and understanding of physics. Its publishing company, IOP Publishing, is a world leader in professional scientific communications.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.iop.org\">https://www.iop.org</a></p></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<p></p>\n                </div>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n<!-- Branded journal header ends -->\n</div> <!-- end secondary-header -->\n<!-- Secondary header ends --><div class=\"da1-da2\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/ScholarlyArticle\" id=\"page-content\">\n            <div class=\"da1 ta1 article-head\">\n                <!-- Start Eyebrow block, containing Surtitle and Labels -->\n<div class=\"eyebrow\">\n\t<!-- Start Collection Labels -->\n    <!-- End Collection Labels --> </div>\n<!-- End Eyebrow block -->\n\n<h1 itemprop=\"headline\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-title\">Andromeda's Parachute: A Bright Quadruply Lensed Quasar at <I>z</I>\u00a0=\u00a02.377</h1>\n\n<p class=\"mb-0\">\n\t<span data-authors=\"\">\n\t\t<span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">Kate H. <div id=\"innerContainer\">\n            <a class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" title=\"Close\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\">\n                <span class=\"icon-close\"></span>\n            </a>\n            <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">\n                Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.\n            </p>\n            <form id=\"alertsForm\" class=\"overlay-panel__form\" method=\"post\" action=\"\" role=\"form\" aria-labelledby=\"alerts-box-title\">\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__header\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__logo\"></div>\n                    <span id=\"alerts-box-title\" class=\"replica-h2\">Corridor alerts</span>\n                    <p id=\"alerts-box-desc\">\n                        Receive alerts on all new research papers in American Astronomical Society\n                        (<span class=\"abbr__aas\">A&nbsp;A&nbsp;S&nbsp;</span>) journals as soon as they are published.\n                        Select your desired journals and corridors below. You will need to select a minimum of one corridor.\n                    </p>\n                </div>\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__container\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__col\">\n                        <fieldset id=\"alerts-corridors-list\">\n                            <legend id=\"corridors-title\" class=\"overlay-panel__heading replica-h3 mb-05\">Corridors</legend>\n                        </fieldset>\n                    </div>\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__col\">\n                        <fieldset id=\"alerts-journals-list\">\n                            <legend id=\"journals-title\" class=\"overlay-panel__heading replica-h3 mb-05\">Journals</legend>\n                        </fieldset>\n                    </div>\n                    <div class=\"boxout-bg-blue-light overlay-panel__extra-info\">\n                        <p>\n                            Please note, The Astrophysical Journal Letters (ApJL) and Research Notes of the AAS (RNAAS)\n                            do not currently use the corridors.\n                        </p>\n                    </div>\n                </div>\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__footer\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__inner-footer\">\n                        <input id=\"update-alerts\" type=\"submit\" value=\"Create alert\" class=\"btn btn-default overlay-panel__btn\" role=\"button\">\n                        <div class=\"icon-spinner spinner overlay-panel__loading\"></div>\n                    </div>\n                </div>\n            </form>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- End TOC Subjects Popup -->\n            <p class=\"mb-0\"><a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert jnl-email-alert--corridors-info\" href=\"https://journals.aas.org/corridors.html\"\n               target=\"_blank\" title=\"Find out more about AAS corridors.\">\n                What are corridors? <span class=\"icon-newtab\">\n            </a></p>\n        </div>\n\n    <!-- End Email Alert -->\n<!-- End Email Alert --><!-- Start Citation Alert Link -->\n                        <p>\n<div class=\"jnl-notifications-wrapper\">\n    <a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert\" href=\"https://myiopscience.iop.org/signin?origin=a0&return=https%3A%2F%2Fiopscience.iop.org%2Fmyiopscience%2Falerts%2Fsubscribe%3FarticleID%3D0004-637X%2F859%2F2%2F146\"><span\n            class=\"icon-alarm icon-alarm--jhp\"></span>Create citation alert</a>\n</div><!-- End Citation Alert Link -->\n                    </div>\n\t\t</div>\n    </div>\n    <!-- Article information ends -->\n<!-- Start Info top-->\n    <!-- end Info top --><div class=\"article-content\">\n\t<span id=\"articleId\" class=\"hide\">0004-637X/859/2/146</span>\n<!-- Start Abstract -->\n    <h2 id=\"artAbst\" class=\"collapse-blocked\">Abstract</h2>\n        <!-- Start article video abstract -->\n\t<!-- End article video abstract -->\n\t<div class=\"article-text wd-jnl-art-abstract cf\" itemprop=\"description\">\n             <P>We present Keck Cosmic Web Imager spectroscopy of the four putative images of the lensed quasar candidate J014710+463040 recently discovered by Berghea et al. The data verify the source as a quadruply lensed, broad absorption-line quasar having <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"${z}_{{\\rm{S}}}=2.377\\,\\pm \\,0.007$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/apjaaaeb7ieqn1.gif\"></IMG>. We detect intervening absorption in the Fe <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> <I>\u03bb\u03bb</I>2586, 2600, Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> <I>\u03bb\u03bb</I>2796, 2803, and/or C <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> <I>\u03bb\u03bb</I>1548, 1550 transitions in eight foreground systems, three of which have redshifts consistent with the photometric-redshift estimate reported for the lensing galaxy (<I>z</I> <SUB>L</SUB>\u00a0\u2248\u00a00.57). The source images probe these absorbers over transverse physical scales of \u22480.3\u201322 kpc, permitting assessment of the variation in metal-line equivalent width <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}}}$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/apjaaaeb7ieqn2.gif\"></IMG> as a function of sight-line separation. We measure differences in <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/apjaaaeb7ieqn3.gif\"></IMG> of &lt;40% across most of the sight-line pairs subtending 8\u201322 kpc, suggestive of a high degree of spatial coherence for the Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>-absorbing material. <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}},2600}$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/apjaaaeb7ieqn4.gif\"></IMG> varies by &gt;50% over the same scales across the majority of sight-line pairs, while C <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> absorption exhibits a wide range in <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}},1548}$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/apjaaaeb7ieqn5.gif\"></IMG> differences of \u22485%\u201380% within transverse distances of <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/lesssim.gif\" alt=\"lesssim\" align=\"baseline\" />3 kpc. These spatial variations are consistent with those measured in intervening absorbers detected toward lensed quasars drawn from the literature, in which <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/apjaaaeb7ieqn6.gif\"></IMG> and <IMG ALIGN=\"MIDDLE\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}},1548}$\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/apjaaaeb7ieqn7.gif\"></IMG> vary by \u226420% in 35\u00a0\u00b1\u00a07% and 47\u00a0\u00b1\u00a06% of sight lines separated by &lt;10 kpc, respectively. J014710+463040 is one of only a handful of <I>z</I>\u00a0&gt;\u00a02 quadruply lensed systems for which all four source images are very bright (<I>r</I>\u00a0=\u00a015.4\u201317.7 mag) and are easily separated in ground-based seeing conditions. As such, it is an ideal candidate for higher-resolution spectroscopy probing the spatial variation in the kinematic structure and physical state of intervening absorbers.</P> </div>\n    <!-- End abstract -->\n<!-- Start Export citation and abstract tools -->\n\t<p>\n\t\t<small>Export citation and abstract</small>\n\t\t<span class=\"btn-multi-block\">\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/859/2/146&doi=10.3847/1538-4357/aaaeb7&exportFormat=iopexport_bib&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-bib\" title=\"Export BibTex\">BibTeX</a>\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/859/2/146&doi=10.3847/1538-4357/aaaeb7&exportFormat=iopexport_ris&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-ris\" title=\"Export RIS\">RIS</a>\n\t\t</span>\n\t</p>\n<!-- End Export citation and abstract tools -->\n<!-- Start AAS Related Links -->\n<div class=\"reveal-container reveal-closed reveal-plus-icon bdt-1 mt-2 mb-2 wd-jnl-art-article-aas-related-links\">\n  <div class=\"replica-h3 mt-0\">\n    <a href=\"#\" class=\"reveal-trigger\" data-reveal-label-alt=\"Hide related links\">Related links</a>\n  </div>\n  <div class=\"reveal-content\">\n    <div class=\"article-meta\"> \n      <ul>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2018ApJ...859..146R\" target=\"_blank\">NASA ADS Record <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-ref?querymethod=bib&simbo=on&bibcode=2018ApJ...859..146R\" target=\"_blank\">Simbad Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"/journal/0004-637X/page/About%20Related%20Links\" target=\"_blank\">About Related Links</a></li>\n      \t</ul>\n    </div>\n  </div>\n</div>\n<!-- Start info bottom -->\n    <!-- End info bottom -->\n<!-- Start article full text -->\n\t<div xmlns:book=\"http://api.iop.org/Book/1.0/\" itemprop=\"articleBody\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-full-text article-text\">\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjaaaeb7s1\" name=\"apjaaaeb7s1\">1.\u00a0Introduction</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>Strong gravitational lensing of high-redshift quasars has proven to be a powerful astrophysical and cosmological tool for a myriad of applications. Experiments range from high-fidelity spectroscopy probing the structure of the broad-line region surrounding the host active galactic nuclei (e.g., Nemiroff <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib33a\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib33a\">1988</a>; Sluse et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib46\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib46\">2012</a>) to time domain observations constraining cosmological parameters (e.g., Bonvin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib4\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib4\">2017</a>). However, the brightest and most valuable of these sources are rare. Candidate lensed quasars may now be efficiently identified via color and morphological selection techniques (e.g., Schechter et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib42\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib42\">2017</a>) or using variability criteria (e.g., Kochanek et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib26\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib26\">2006</a>) in wide-field optical and near-infrared imaging surveys (e.g., Inada et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib22\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib22\">2012</a>; Diehl et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib14\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib14\">2014</a>; Shanks et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib43\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib43\">2015</a>). Follow-up spectroscopy is then always required to confirm the nature of the system.</p><p>Recently, Berghea et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib3\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib3\">2017</a>) identified a quadruply lensed quasar candidate in imaging obtained by the Panoramic Survey Telescope and Rapid Response System (hereafter PS1; Chambers et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib5\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib5\">2016</a>). Astrometry of the components implies distances between source images of \u22481<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />3\u20133<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />4. They reported satisfactory spectral energy distribution (SED) fits to the source photometry for quasar templates at both <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn8.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{{\\rm{S}}}={0.820}_{-0.014}^{+0.018}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{{\\rm{S}}}={0.820}_{-0.014}^{+0.018}</script></span></span> and <em>z</em><sub>S</sub>\u00a0\u2248\u00a02.6. Additionally, they found that SED modeling of the photometry of the prospective lens galaxy yields a best-fit redshift of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn9.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{{\\rm{L}}}={0.57}_{-0.13}^{+0.20}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{{\\rm{L}}}={0.57}_{-0.13}^{+0.20}</script></span></span>.</p><p>In principle, images of a source QSO at <em>z</em><sub>S</sub>\u00a0\u2248\u00a02.6 lensed by a foreground system at <em>z</em><sub>L</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.57 and separated by 1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />3\u20133<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />4 probe physical scales of \u22480.5\u201325 kpc at <em>z</em>\u00a0\u2248\u00a00.5\u20132. Such a configuration is highly valuable for the study of the transverse small-scale coherence of circumgalactic medium (CGM) absorption. The brightness of this particular candidate (<em>r</em>\u00a0=\u00a015.4\u201317.7 mag) and relatively large separation of the source images enable high-signal-to-noise (S/N) spectroscopy with maximum efficiency.</p><p>In this paper, we present spectroscopy from the recently commissioned Keck Cosmic Web Imager (KCWI; P. Morrissey et al. 2018, in preparation) confirming that this system (J014710+463040) is a quadruply lensed quasar at <em>z</em><sub>S</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn10.gif\" alt=\"$2.377$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">2.377</script></span></span>. We then analyze intervening metal-line absorption systems detected along these sight lines in conjunction with additional systems collected from the literature for constraints on their spatial coherence. Given the source image configuration and its location on the sky, we refer to this object as Andromeda's Parachute.<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7fn1\">7</a></sup>\n We adopt the WMAP5 cosmology (<em>H</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0=\u00a070.2 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn11.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{km}\\,{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{km}\\,{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}</script></span></span> Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn12.gif\" alt=\"${{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{{\\rm{M}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{{\\rm{M}}}</script></span></span>\u00a0=\u00a00.277, and \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.723; Komatsu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib27\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib27\">2009</a>) throughout this work unless otherwise specified.</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjaaaeb7s2\" name=\"apjaaaeb7s2\">2.\u00a0Observations</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>We observed J014710+463040 with KCWI on the night of 2017 June 21 UT. The instrument was configured with the small image slicer and BL grating, providing a spatial sampling of 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />35 pix<sup>\u22121</sup> and a spectral resolution of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn13.gif\" alt=\"${ \\mathcal R }\\approx 5000$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{ \\mathcal R }\\approx 5000</script></span></span>. The field-of-view of KCWI in this configuration is 8<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />4\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a020<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />4, permitting simultaneous spectroscopy of all four source images in a single pointing (e.g., Wisotzki et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib55\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib55\">2003</a>). PS1 imaging of the target<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7fn2\">8</a></sup>\n and the placement of the KCWI footprint are shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7f1\">1</a> (left panel). The image slices were oriented at a position angle of 97<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/fdg.gif\" alt=\"fdg\" align=\"baseline\" />1. We obtained two exposures of 600 s each while the target was at airmass \u22481.5\u20131.6.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaaaeb7f1\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaaaeb7f1\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7f1_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 1.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 1.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7f1_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 1.</strong>\u00a0Left: PS1 <em>giy</em> color image (Chambers et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib5\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib5\">2016</a>) of the lensed quasar system. Each source image is labeled A\u2013D (brightest to faintest) as in Berghea et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib3\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib3\">2017</a>). The small cyan square shows the approximate location of the lensing galaxy. The thick white outline indicates the placement of the KCWI 20<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />4\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a08<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />4 field-of-view over the target. The thin white lines show the width of each 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />35 image slicer within the KCWI footprint. Right: KCWI image of the target obtained from one 600 s exposure. The grayscale shows the flux density averaged over the wavelength range <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn14.gif\" alt=\"$4200\\,\\mathring{\\rm A} \\lt {\\lambda }_{\\mathrm{obs}}\\lt 4300\\,\\mathring{\\rm A} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">4200\\,\\mathring{\\rm A} \\lt {\\lambda }_{\\mathrm{obs}}\\lt 4300\\,\\mathring{\\rm A}</script></span></span> in each spaxel of the rectified datacube. The red boxes indicate the placement and size of the apertures used to generate the 1D spectra shown in Figure <a href=\"#apjaaaeb7f2\">2</a>.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaaaeb7f1\" href=\"/0004-637X/859/2/146/downloadFigure/figure/apjaaaeb7f1\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaaaeb7f1\" href=\"/0004-637X/859/2/146/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaaaeb7f1\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>The data were reduced using the publicly available <tt>kderp</tt> package.<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7fn3\">9</a></sup>\n We used in-house software to rectify the curved object traces along the cube resulting from differential atmospheric dispersion. The final rectified KCWI image, averaged over the wavelength range 4200 \u00c5\u00a0&lt;\u00a0<em>\u03bb</em><sub>obs</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a04300 \u00c5, is shown in the right-hand panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7f1\">1</a>.</p><p>To extract 1D spectra from this rectified cube, we performed a simple sum of the flux over the spatial dimensions in 5\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a05 pixel sub-cubes centered on each source image (see red apertures in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7f1\">1</a>, right panel). A sky spectrum was extracted in the same manner from an off-source region of the datacube and was subtracted from each of the on-source spectra. We then co-added the 1D spectra extracted from the two 600 s exposures for each source image. These co-added 1D spectra are shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7f2\">2</a>, and have median S/N per pixel measured redward of the quasar <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn15.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{Ly}\\alpha $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{Ly}\\alpha</script></span></span> emission line of ~180, ~160, ~130, and ~45 in images A, B, C, and D, respectively.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaaaeb7f2\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaaaeb7f2\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7f2_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 2.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 2.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7f2_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 2.</strong>\u00a0Extracted 1D spectra of the four images indicated in Figure <a href=\"#apjaaaeb7f1\">1</a> demonstrating that the source is a lensed BAL quasar at <em>z</em><sub>S</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0<span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn16.gif\" alt=\"$2.377$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">2.377</script></span></span>. Intrinsic absorption features extend up to \u224810,000 <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn17.gif\" alt=\"$\\,\\mathrm{km}\\,{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\,\\mathrm{km}\\,{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}</script></span></span> blueward of each emission line (e.g., C <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> at <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn18.gif\" alt=\"${\\lambda }_{\\mathrm{obs}}\\approx 5200\\mathring{\\rm A} $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\lambda }_{\\mathrm{obs}}\\approx 5200\\mathring{\\rm A}</script></span></span>). Intervening metal-line absorption systems are indicated with vertical colored marks, and are in most cases detected along all four sight lines.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaaaeb7f2\" href=\"/0004-637X/859/2/146/downloadFigure/figure/apjaaaeb7f2\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaaaeb7f2\" href=\"/0004-637X/859/2/146/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaaaeb7f2\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjaaaeb7s3\" name=\"apjaaaeb7s3\">3.\u00a0Spectroscopic Analysis</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7f2\">2</a> makes evident that each source image originates from the same high-redshift quasar. The complex absorption features blanketing the quasar's broad <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn19.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{Ly}\\alpha $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{Ly}\\alpha</script></span></span>, Si <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>, and C <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> emission lines (at <em>\u03bb</em><sub>obs</sub>\u00a0~\u00a04100 \u00c5, 4700 \u00c5, and 5150 \u00c5) indicate that it belongs to the broad absorption-line (BAL) quasar subclass (Weymann et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib54\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib54\">1991</a>).</p><h3 id=\"apjaaaeb7s3-1\" name=\"apjaaaeb7s3-1\">3.1.\u00a0Redshift of J014710+463040</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>To measure the quasar redshift, we cross-correlate the quasar template used in Hewett &amp; Wild (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib21\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib21\">2010</a>) with each of the four spectra shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7f2\">2</a>. Given the BAL nature of J014710+463040, we exclude the template blueward of restframe <em>\u03bb</em>\u00a0=\u00a01250 \u00c5 (i.e., the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn20.gif\" alt=\"$\\mathrm{Ly}\\alpha $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\mathrm{Ly}\\alpha</script></span></span> and N <span class=\"small-caps\">v</span> QSO emission lines). We fit a Gaussian to the peak of the cross-correlation, adopting the best-fit Gaussian centroid as the redshift for each source image. We adopt the mean and sample standard deviation of the four measurements as the source redshift <em>z</em><sub>S</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn21.gif\" alt=\"$2.377$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">2.377</script></span></span>\u00a0\u00b1\u00a0<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn22.gif\" alt=\"$0.007$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0.007</script></span></span>. Observations at longer wavelengths are needed to constrain the redshift to higher precision.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjaaaeb7s3-2\" name=\"apjaaaeb7s3-2\">3.2.\u00a0Intervening Absorption</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>We visually inspected each spectrum to identify foreground metal-line absorption, focusing in particular on the identification of C <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> <em>\u03bb\u03bb</em>1548, 1550, Al <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> <em>\u03bb</em>1670, Al <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span> <em>\u03bb\u03bb</em>1854, 1862, Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> <em>\u03bb\u03bb</em>2796, 2803, and Fe <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> <em>\u03bb\u03bb</em>2586, 2600 transitions known to arise in collisionally ionized or photoionized diffuse media at temperatures of ~10<sup>4\u22125</sup> K (Bergeron &amp; Stasi\u0144ska <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib2\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib2\">1986</a>). We used the Python package <tt>linetools</tt><sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7fn4\">10</a></sup>\n to interactively fit a spline function to the continuum of each quasar image and produce continuum-normalized spectra. We then used the interactive IGMGuesses GUI available with the <tt>pyigm</tt> Python package<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7fn5\">11</a></sup>\n to select velocity ranges for each absorber and fit Voigt profiles to determine the wavelength centroid (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn23.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}</script></span></span>). We measured the rest equivalent width (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn24.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}</script></span></span>) of each line using a boxcar sum of the flux decrement over the selected velocity range.</p><p>We summarize these systems in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7t1\">1</a> and indicate them with vertical lines in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7f2\">2</a>. Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7t1\">1</a> also indicates transitions affected by blending with BAL features. The reported uncertainties in the rest equivalent widths, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn25.gif\" alt=\"${\\sigma }_{{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\sigma }_{{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}}</script></span></span>, do not include errors associated with continuum normalization. The effect of uncertainties in continuum-level placement on the measurement of equivalent width can often be significant, especially for BAL quasars observed at the medium spectral resolution of our KCWI configuration. However, systematic errors in continuum placement are likely to be similar across the four sight lines. We therefore expect the analysis of the relative variation in <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn26.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}</script></span></span> at a given <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn27.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}</script></span></span> to be insensitive to these uncertainties.</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjaaaeb7t1\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 1.</b>\u00a0\nIntervening Absorption-line Systems\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" these absorbers is indicated above the corresponding source image spectrum in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7f2\">2</a>.</p>\n<a name=\"apjaaaeb7t1fna\" computing the boxcar <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img and then computing the sum of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}</script></span></span>\u00a0+\u00a03 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span }_{{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}}</script></span></span>.\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/859/2/146/suppdata/apjaaaeb7t1_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/aaaeb7\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a>Typeset images: <a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset-multiple typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/859/2/146/suppdata/apjaaaeb7t1_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">1</a> <a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset-multiple typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/859/2/146/suppdata/apjaaaeb7t1a_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">2</a> </span></p></div><p>The strongest metal absorber in our sample (the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn46.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}</script></span></span>\u00a0= 0.98 \u00c5 Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> system at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn47.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}</script></span></span>\u00a0=\u00a00.7583) is securely detected only in sight line D. As the observed wavelength range of this system overlaps with that of the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn48.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}</script></span></span>\u00a0=\u00a02.177 C <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> system detected in sight lines A\u2013C, we report an upper limit on <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn49.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}</script></span></span> at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn50.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}</script></span></span>\u00a0=\u00a00.7583 in these latter sight lines by first computing the boxcar <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn51.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn52.gif\" alt=\"${\\sigma }_{{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\sigma }_{{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}}</script></span></span> over the velocity range assigned to this system in sight line D, and then computing the sum of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn53.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}</script></span></span>\u00a0+\u00a03 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn54.gif\" alt=\"${\\sigma }_{{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\sigma }_{{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}}</script></span></span>. These limits are likewise included in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7t1\">1</a>.</p><p>We show sections of our QSO spectroscopy surrounding the C <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> absorption systems listed in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7t1\">1</a> in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7f3\">3</a>, and show the spectroscopy of systems exhibiting Fe <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> and/or Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> absorption in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7f4\">4</a>. Each spectrum is color coded to indicate the corresponding QSO image (red, orange, green, and blue for images A, B, C, and D, respectively). Unassociated absorption features are indicated with dotted histograms. Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7f3\">3</a> demonstrates the strong similarity between the C <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> line profiles for our highest-redshift systems (at <em>z</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a02), while the system at <em>z</em>\u00a0\u2248\u00a01.76 exhibits a significant change in absorption depth in sight line D versus A, B, and C. The velocity structure of the low-ion absorption shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7f4\">4</a> tends to vary more significantly from sight line to sight line, with two of the systems (at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.577 and <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.049) exhibiting a velocity shear of <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/gsim.gif\" alt=\"gsim\" align=\"baseline\" />100 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn55.gif\" alt=\"$\\,\\mathrm{km}\\,{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\,\\mathrm{km}\\,{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}</script></span></span>, and with all of the systems exhibiting significant differences in the depth of the line profile in at least one transition.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaaaeb7f3\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaaaeb7f3\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7f3_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 3.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 3.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7f3_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 3.</strong>\u00a0Continuum-normalized lensed QSO spectroscopy centered on C <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> <em>\u03bb\u03bb</em>1548, 1550 absorption in the high-redshift (<em>z</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a01.6) intervening systems listed in Table <a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7t1\">1</a> (excepting the system at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.7526 detected in sight line A). The red, orange, green, and blue spectra were extracted from QSO images A, B, C, and D, respectively. Relative velocities of 0 <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn56.gif\" alt=\"$\\,\\mathrm{km}\\,{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\,\\mathrm{km}\\,{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}</script></span></span> correspond to the redshift centroid measured in sight line D (or in sight line A if the system is not detected in D). Strong absorption associated with material at a redshift other than that indicated above each column is indicated with dotted histograms.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaaaeb7f3\" href=\"/0004-637X/859/2/146/downloadFigure/figure/apjaaaeb7f3\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaaaeb7f3\" href=\"/0004-637X/859/2/146/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaaaeb7f3\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaaaeb7f4\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaaaeb7f4\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7f4_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 4.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 4.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7f4_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 4.</strong>\u00a0Continuum-normalized lensed QSO spectroscopy centered on Fe <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> <em>\u03bb\u03bb</em>2586, 2600 (top two rows) and Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> <em>\u03bb\u03bb</em>2796, 2803 (bottom two rows) absorption in the <em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a01.5 systems listed in Table <a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7t1\">1</a>. As in Figure <a href=\"#apjaaaeb7f3\">3</a>, spectra are color coded by the corresponding lens image. Relative velocities of 0 <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn57.gif\" alt=\"$\\,\\mathrm{km}\\,{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\,\\mathrm{km}\\,{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}</script></span></span> correspond to the redshift centroid measured in sight line D. We do not show our spectroscopic coverage of the Fe <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> transitions associated with the <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.577 system at <em>\u03bb</em><sub>obs</sub>\u00a0~\u00a04100  \u00c5 as they fall among the intrinsic BAL features blanketing the Ly<em>\u03b1</em> emission line of the QSO. Spectroscopy shown in panels labeled with \"<em>b</em>\" at bottom right is affected by weaker BAL absorption.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaaaeb7f4\" href=\"/0004-637X/859/2/146/downloadFigure/figure/apjaaaeb7f4\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaaaeb7f4\" href=\"/0004-637X/859/2/146/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaaaeb7f4\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>Given the complexity of the spectra of J014710+463040 and the resolution of these data, we do not attempt to identify metal absorption lines in the Ly<em>\u03b1</em> forest, and we are likely missing absorption lines contaminated by the BAL features dominating the regions near the quasar emission lines. Higher resolution data will be required to perform a comprehensive analysis of intervening absorption; however, we discuss some preliminary findings based on the present data set in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7s3-4\">3.4</a>.</p><p>The KCWI data were not of sufficient depth to detect emission from the lensing galaxy, and hence cannot directly constrain its redshift. We note that three intervening absorbers are found to have redshifts within the \u00b11-<em>\u03c3</em> photometric errors of the Berghea et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib3\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib3\">2017</a>) redshift estimate for the lens (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn58.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{{\\rm{L}}}={0.57}_{-0.13}^{+0.20}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{{\\rm{L}}}={0.57}_{-0.13}^{+0.20}</script></span></span>); in addition, two of these systems are detected in all four source images. One of these latter systems, identified at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn59.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}</script></span></span>\u00a0=\u00a00.5775 in sight line A, has a redshift very close to the best-fit photometric estimate. Moreover, source image D (the image closest to the expected position of the lens in projection) exhibits a two-component absorbing structure in the system near <em>z</em><sub>L</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.57 (having <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn60.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}</script></span></span>\u00a0=\u00a00.5762 and 0.5768). These double components are not evident in any of the other sight lines at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn61.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}</script></span></span>\u00a0=\u00a00.577, and are suggestive of the complex, multiple-component Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> absorbers typically observed close to bright galaxies (e.g., Kacprzak et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib24\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib24\">2010</a>; Chen et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib6\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib6\">2014</a>). Sight line D also exhibits strong Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> absorption at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn62.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}</script></span></span>\u00a0\u2248\u00a00.76 that is not detected in the other sight lines (and for which we list upper limits in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7t1\">1</a>), raising the possibility that this <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn63.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}</script></span></span>\u00a0\u2248\u00a00.76 system is associated with the lensing galaxy. Without a spectrum of the lens itself, we cannot be certain of its redshift; however, the detection of absorption in every sight line at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn64.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}</script></span></span>\u00a0\u2248\u00a00.577, its complex velocity structure in sight line D, and the consistency of this redshift with photometric constraints from Berghea et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib3\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib3\">2017</a>) leads us to adopt <em>z</em><sub>L</sub>\u00a0= <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn65.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}</script></span></span>\u00a0=\u00a00.5768 in our analysis below.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjaaaeb7s3-3\" name=\"apjaaaeb7s3-3\">3.3.\u00a0Sight Line Geometry</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>To compute the transverse separation of the four sight lines as a function of absorber redshift, we refer to Equation (5) in Cooke et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib10\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib10\">2010</a>):</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjaaaeb7eqn1\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7eqn1.gif\" alt=\"Equation (1)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&{S}_{0}=\\displaystyle \\frac{{\\theta }_{\\mathrm{obs}}{D}_{{\\rm{L}}}({D}_{{\\rm{S}}}-{D}_{\\mathrm{abs}})}{(1+{z}_{\\mathrm{abs}})({D}_{{\\rm{S}}}-{D}_{{\\rm{L}}})},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t1\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <em>\u03b8</em><sub>obs</sub> is the observed angular separation between the sight lines and <em>D</em><sub><em>X</em></sub> is the co-moving distance to the redshift <em>z</em><sub><em>X</em></sub>, with L, S, and \"abs\" indicating the lens, source, and absorber, respectively. For these calculations, we assume that the source is located directly behind the center of mass of the lensing galaxy.</p><p>Adopting <em>z</em><sub>L</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.5768 and a source redshift of <em>z</em><sub>S</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn66.gif\" alt=\"$2.377$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">2.377</script></span></span>, we show the resulting physical separations between all sight-line combinations at the redshifts of several of the systems identified in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7s3-2\">3.2</a> in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7t2\">2</a>. If instead <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn67.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{{\\rm{L}}}=0.6069$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{{\\rm{L}}}=0.6069</script></span></span> or <em>z</em><sub>L</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.7583, for systems with <em>z</em><sub>abs</sub> \u2265 <em>z</em><sub>L</sub> each distance would increase by a factor of 1.07 or 1.48, respectively<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7fn6\">12</a></sup>\n. The J014710+463040 system thus permits assessment of the variation in the strength and velocity structure of foreground absorption on scales of a kiloparsec at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn68.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}</script></span></span>\u00a0\u2248\u00a02, \u22485\u201310 kpc at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn69.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}\\approx 1$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}\\approx 1</script></span></span>, and \u224810\u201320 kpc at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn70.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}</script></span></span>\u00a0\u2248\u00a00.6.</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjaaaeb7t2\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 2.</b>\u00a0\nProjected Distances between Lensed Sight Lines for <em>z</em><sub>L</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.5768\n</p><table valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">A-D</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">3.34</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">12.5</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">8.1</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">2.3</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\"
