rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.80</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/859/2/146/suppdata/apjaaaeb7t2_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/aaaeb7\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/859/2/146/suppdata/apjaaaeb7t2_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div></div><h3 id=\"apjaaaeb7s3-4\" name=\"apjaaaeb7s3-4\">3.4.\u00a0Coherence in <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn78.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}</script></span></span> Across Multiple, Close Sight Lines</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The analysis described in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7s3-2\">3.2</a> revealed 7\u20139 securely detected intervening absorption systems toward every quasar image. For all of these systems, with the exception of the Al <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span> absorbers, the C <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> absorber at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn79.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}</script></span></span>\u00a0=\u00a01.7526 in sight line A, and the Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> absorber at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn80.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}</script></span></span>\u00a0=\u00a00.7583 in sight line D, we detect counterpart absorbers within a velocity range of <em>\u03b4v</em>\u00a0\u00b1\u00a0250 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn81.gif\" alt=\"$\\,\\mathrm{km}\\,{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\,\\mathrm{km}\\,{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}</script></span></span>, with the vast majority of the counterparts lying within <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn82.gif\" alt=\"$\\delta v\\pm 100\\,\\mathrm{km}\\,{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\delta v\\pm 100\\,\\mathrm{km}\\,{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}</script></span></span>. Given the physical separation of the sight lines, this finding is suggestive of absorbing structures extending over relatively large scales (e.g., &gt;5\u201320 kpc at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn83.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}</script></span></span>\u00a0&lt;\u00a01). To quantitatively assess the physical extent of these absorbers and the scale over which their <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn84.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}</script></span></span> varies, we compute the fractional difference in <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn85.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}</script></span></span> values measured at a given <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn86.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}</script></span></span> for each pair of sight lines, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn87.gif\" alt=\"$({W}_{{\\rm{r}},\\mathrm{ion}}^{{\\rm{X}}}-{W}_{{\\rm{r}},\\mathrm{ion}}^{{\\rm{Y}}})/{W}_{{\\rm{r}},\\mathrm{ion}}^{{\\rm{X}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">({W}_{{\\rm{r}},\\mathrm{ion}}^{{\\rm{X}}}-{W}_{{\\rm{r}},\\mathrm{ion}}^{{\\rm{Y}}})/{W}_{{\\rm{r}},\\mathrm{ion}}^{{\\rm{X}}}</script></span></span>, where sight line X has the stronger absorption of the two. We show these fractional differences for Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> (filled circles) and Fe <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> (filled squares) systems in the upper left panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7f5\">5</a> versus the physical separation of the sight line pair (taken from Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7t2\">2</a>). The lower left panel of the Figure shows the same measurements for our C <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> systems (filled circles). Each point is color coded by the corresponding value of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn88.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}},\\mathrm{ion}}^{{\\rm{X}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}},\\mathrm{ion}}^{{\\rm{X}}}</script></span></span>.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaaaeb7f5\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaaaeb7f5\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7f5_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 5.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 5.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7f5_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 5.</strong>\u00a0Left panels: fractional difference in <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn89.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}</script></span></span> as a function of sight-line separation at <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn90.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}</script></span></span> for intervening absorbers detected toward J014710+463040 (filled circles and squares) and toward lensed QSOs analyzed in previous studies (open stars; Young et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib57\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib57\">1981</a>; Foltz et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib18\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib18\">1984</a>; Smette et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib48\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib48\">1992</a>; Crotts et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib12\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib12\">1994</a>; Smette et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib47\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib47\">1995</a>; Monier et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib32\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib32\">1998</a>; Lopez et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib30\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib30\">1999</a>, <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib29\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib29\">2000</a>; Ellison et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib15\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib15\">2004</a>; Rogerson &amp; Hall <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib41\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib41\">2012</a>; Chen et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib6\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib6\">2014</a>). The fractional difference is <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn91.gif\" alt=\"$({W}_{{\\rm{r}},\\mathrm{ion}}^{{\\rm{X}}}-{W}_{{\\rm{r}},\\mathrm{ion}}^{{\\rm{Y}}})/{W}_{{\\rm{r}},\\mathrm{ion}}^{{\\rm{X}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">({W}_{{\\rm{r}},\\mathrm{ion}}^{{\\rm{X}}}-{W}_{{\\rm{r}},\\mathrm{ion}}^{{\\rm{Y}}})/{W}_{{\\rm{r}},\\mathrm{ion}}^{{\\rm{X}}}</script></span></span>, where sight line X has the stronger absorption of the two systems. Points are color coded to indicate <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn92.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}},{\\rm{ion}}}^{X}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}},{\\rm{ion}}}^{X}</script></span></span>, and the vertical scale increases top to bottom (i.e., more to less coherent). The upper panel shows <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn93.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}</script></span></span> offsets in Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> 2796 (filled circles and open stars) and Fe <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> 2600 (filled squares). The lower panel shows the same measurements for C <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> 1548. Middle panels: frequency distributions of fractional difference values shown in the left-most panels. Sight line pairs with secure detections in both images are included in the solid histograms, and pairs which yield lower limits on the fractional difference are included at the value of the limit in the hatched and open histograms. Distributions shown in blue include systems with <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn94.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}}}^{{\\rm{X}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}^{{\\rm{X}}}</script></span></span> &lt; 0.5 \u00c5, and distributions shown in red include systems with <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn94a.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}}}^{{\\rm{X}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}^{{\\rm{X}}}</script></span></span> &gt; 0.5 \u00c5. Right panels: same as middle panels, with blue histograms showing sight line pairs with separations of &lt;5 kpc, and red histograms including sight line pairs at larger physical separations.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaaaeb7f5\" href=\"/0004-637X/859/2/146/downloadFigure/figure/apjaaaeb7f5\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaaaeb7f5\" href=\"/0004-637X/859/2/146/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaaaeb7f5\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>Considering the two Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> systems at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn96.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}</script></span></span>\u00a0\u2248\u00a00.577 and 0.607, we measure small fractional <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn97.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}</script></span></span> differences (&lt;40%) across the full range of sight-line separations (~8\u201322 kpc), pointing to a high degree of coherence over large scales even for these relatively weak absorbers (having <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn98.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}</script></span></span>\u00a0\u2248\u00a00.1\u22120.46 \u00c5). The much stronger (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn99.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}</script></span></span>\u00a0=\u00a00.98 \u00c5) <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn100.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}</script></span></span>\u00a0\u2248\u00a00.758 Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> system, on the other hand, yields lower limits for fractional <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn101.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}</script></span></span> differences of <img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/gsim.gif\" alt=\"gsim\" align=\"baseline\" />85% at separations of ~17 kpc.</p><p>The Fe <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> system at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn102.gif\" alt=\"${z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{z}_{\\mathrm{abs}}</script></span></span>\u00a0\u2248\u00a01.049 on the whole exhibits larger absorption strength variations than our Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> systems, yielding fractional <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn103.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}},2600}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}},2600}</script></span></span> differences of \u224825%\u201390% between every sight line pair. We find that the four C <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> systems likewise exhibit a quite high degree of variation, with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn104.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}},1548}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}},1548}</script></span></span> differences ranging between \u22485 and 80% over 0.3\u20133 kpc separations. Such a wide range of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn105.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}},1548}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}},1548}</script></span></span> values points to gas densities which vary on sub-kiloparsec scales for the weakest of these absorbers (with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn106.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}},1548}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}},1548}</script></span></span>\u00a0~\u00a00.02\u20130.05 \u00c5).</p><p>Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7f5\">5</a> also includes similar measurements collected from the literature analyzing intervening C <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> 1548 and Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> 2796 absorption along lensed quasar sight lines. For each system, we adopt updated constraints on <em>z</em><sub>L</sub> where available and recalculate the transverse physical sight-line separations assuming the WMAP5 cosmology (Komatsu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib27\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib27\">2009</a>, with one exception described below). In detail, we include systems from Young et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib57\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib57\">1981</a>), Foltz et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib18\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib18\">1984</a>), Smette et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib48\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib48\">1992</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib47\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib47\">1995</a>), Crotts et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib12\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib12\">1994</a>), Monier et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib32\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib32\">1998</a>), Lopez et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib30\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib30\">1999</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib29\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib29\">2000</a>), Ellison et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib15\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib15\">2004</a>), Rogerson &amp; Hall (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib41\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib41\">2012</a>), and Chen et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib6\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib6\">2014</a>). For absorbers from Foltz et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib18\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib18\">1984</a>), we assume <em>z</em><sub>L</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.49 and an angular sight-line separation of 7<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />13 (Sol et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib49\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib49\">1984</a>). In the case of absorbers from Smette et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib47\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib47\">1995</a>), we assume <em>z</em><sub>L</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01 as in Lopez et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib30\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib30\">1999</a>). The Monier et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib32\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib32\">1998</a>) study focused on the Cloverleaf lens, for which <em>z</em><sub>L</sub> is still not precisely known; here we adopt <em>z</em><sub>L</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.88 as estimated in Goicoechea &amp; Shalyapin (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib20\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib20\">2010</a>). Rogerson &amp; Hall (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib41\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib41\">2012</a>) reported <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn107.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}</script></span></span> measurements for spectra of the Einstein Cross published by Rauch et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib40\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib40\">2002</a>), and for which we adopt astrometry from Crane et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib11\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib11\">1991</a>). We also include Rogerson &amp; Hall (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib41\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib41\">2012</a>) measurements for doubly and quadruply lensed quasar spectroscopy published by Churchill et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib9\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib9\">2003</a>), Oguri et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib35\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib35\">2004</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib36\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib36\">2008</a>), and Kayo et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib25\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib25\">2010</a>). For absorbers in paired sight lines listed in Rogerson &amp; Hall (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib41\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib41\">2012</a>), as well as for all absorbers listed in Chen et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib6\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib6\">2014</a>), we do not compute sight-line separations, and instead adopt the physical distances listed in those works (although they assume slightly different cosmological parameters).</p><p>The fractional <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn108.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}</script></span></span> differences (or lower limits in cases in which an absorber is securely detected along only one sight line) for these systems are indicated with open stars in the left-hand panels of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7f5\">5</a>. Here we exclude systems that yield fractional <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn109.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}</script></span></span> differences or limits less than 0.0, as well as constraints for which the 1<em>\u03c3</em> uncertainty in the fractional <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn110.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}</script></span></span> difference is greater than 0.5. We also exclude lower limits from the sample if they are &lt;0.05. After making these exclusions, the final sample of fractional <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn111.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}</script></span></span> difference measurements includes constraints from 98 sight line pairs probing Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> absorption and 104 sight line pairs probing C <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> systems.</p><p>The predominant feature of both top and bottom left-hand panels in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7f5\">5</a> is the significant scatter over the full range of physical separations shown, pointing to a high degree of variation in the spatial coherence for both metal-line transitions. However, we also note a higher incidence of non-detections in paired sight lines probing Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> absorption relative to the sample probing C <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> systems, and that these non-detections arise frequently even among close sight line pairs.</p><p>To make this comparison more explicit, the middle panels of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7f5\">5</a> show the distributions of these fractional <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn112.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}</script></span></span> differences for subsamples having maximum <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn113.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}</script></span></span> values &lt;0.5 \u00c5 (in blue) and &gt;0.5 \u00c5 (in red). Systems with secure detections in both sight lines are included in the solid histograms, and systems yielding lower limits on the fractional <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn114.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}</script></span></span> difference are included in the open and hatched histograms. A total of 34 (or 35%) of the Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> systems yield lower limits on the fractional <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn115.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}</script></span></span> difference of &gt;0.75, while only 9 of the 104 total C <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> systems exhibit such low fractional differences. To quantitatively assess the significance of the differences in these distributions, we use the Python package <tt>lifelines</tt><sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7fn7\">13</a></sup>\n to perform a survival analysis. Because our data set is characterized by left censorship (in that non-detections represent upper bounds), rather than comparing the distributions of fractional <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn116.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}</script></span></span>\u00a0differences, we compare distributions of the quantity <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn117.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}},\\mathrm{ion}}^{{\\rm{Y}}}/{W}_{{\\rm{r}},\\mathrm{ion}}^{{\\rm{X}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}},\\mathrm{ion}}^{{\\rm{Y}}}/{W}_{{\\rm{r}},\\mathrm{ion}}^{{\\rm{X}}}</script></span></span> so that the censored data corresponds to upper limits. A log-rank test comparing the survival distributions of this ratio for the full Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> versus C <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> samples yields a p-value &lt;10<sup>\u22128</sup>, ruling out the null hypothesis that these data sets are drawn from the same parent population.</p><p>However, for a given ion, a comparison of the red versus blue histograms in these middle panels is not suggestive of significantly different distributions. Log-rank tests performed as described above yield p-values of 0.32\u20130.48, and hence do not rule out the null hypothesis that the fractional <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn118.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}</script></span></span> differences for subsamples divided by maximum <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn119.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}</script></span></span> are drawn from the same parent population. We thus do not find evidence for a relationship between the degree of coherence and absorber strength.</p><p>The right-hand panels of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7f5\">5</a> show fractional <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn120.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}</script></span></span> difference distributions for subsamples with sight line separations &lt;5 kpc (blue) and &gt;5 kpc (red). The C <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> systems in particular have small fractional differences with much higher frequency at small separations. Log-rank tests yield p-values of 0.055 and &lt;10<sup>\u22124</sup> for the Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> and C <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> distributions, respectively, thus securely ruling out the null hypothesis that subsamples at &lt;5 kpc versus &gt;5 kpc separations are drawn from the same parent population in the case of the latter transition.</p><p>An alternative way of assessing the degree of coherence of a set of absorbers as a function of physical distance is to consider the frequency with which the absorbers exhibit fractional <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn121.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}</script></span></span>\u00a0differences lower than a given coherence level, <em>f</em><sub>co</sub>. In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7f6\">6</a>, we show the fraction of absorbers having fractional <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn122.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}</script></span></span> differences lower than <em>f</em><sub>co</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.2 and <em>f</em><sub>co</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.5 in subsamples with physical separations &lt;10 kpc, between 10 and 50 kpc, and &gt;50 kpc. Within 10 kpc, 64% of the sample Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> systems have fractional <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn123.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}</script></span></span> differences of &lt;0.5, and 35% have fractional <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn124.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}</script></span></span> differences of &lt;0.2. At separations greater than 10 kpc, fractional <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn125.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}</script></span></span> differences &lt;0.2 are more infrequent; however, fractional <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn126.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}</script></span></span> differences &lt;0.5 persist in nearly half of the systems. Such small <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn127.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}</script></span></span> variations are suggestive of Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>-absorbing clouds or cloud complexes extending over areas several kiloparsecs across for both strong and weak Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> systems.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjaaaeb7f6\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjaaaeb7f6\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7f6_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 6.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 6.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7f6_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 6.</strong>\u00a0Incidence rate of fractional <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn128.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}</script></span></span> differences less than a given coherence limit (<em>f</em><sub>co</sub>) in three bins of sight-line separation. Incidence rates for Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> 2796 absorbers are indicated in solid cyan (for <em>f</em><sub>co</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.2) and open blue (for <em>f</em><sub>co</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.5) squares, and incidence rates for C <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> 1548 absorbers are plotted in solid orange and open red circles. The horizontal error bars show the range in physical separation included in each bin, and the <em>x</em>-axis location of each point has been slightly offset from the corresponding bin midpoint to improve legibility. Vertical error bars show the \u00b134th percentile Wilson score confidence intervals. While both <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn129.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}</script></span></span> and <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn130.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}},1548}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}},1548}</script></span></span> vary by &lt;20% in about half of the sight line pairs within &lt;10 kpc, such a high degree of coherence is rare among Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> systems at &gt;10 kpc separations.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjaaaeb7f6\" href=\"/0004-637X/859/2/146/downloadFigure/figure/apjaaaeb7f6\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjaaaeb7f6\" href=\"/0004-637X/859/2/146/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjaaaeb7f6\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>C <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> systems exhibit a yet higher degree of coherence, with \u224880\u201390% of systems having fractional <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn131.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}},1548}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}},1548}</script></span></span> differences &lt;0.5 out to physical separations of 50 kpc, and with \u224845%\u201370% of systems varying by &lt;20% over the same scales. It is only beyond separations of 50 kpc that the incidence of coherent absorption drops to &lt;20% (and is comparably low for both transitions). Indeed, this analysis is suggestive of a scenario in which it is common for C <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> absorption to fluctuate by &lt;20% over the scale subtended by a typical host dark matter halo (hosting, e.g., a Lyman Break Galaxy with virial radius &lt;90 kpc; Adelberger et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib1\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib1\">2005</a>; Steidel et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib50\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib50\">2010</a>).</p></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjaaaeb7s4\" name=\"apjaaaeb7s4\">4.\u00a0Discussion</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>The study of intervening absorption-line systems observed in background quasar spectroscopy has proven essential for assessing, e.g., the neutral gas content of the Universe (Wolfe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib56\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib56\">2005</a>) and the evolution of its metal content (Simcoe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib45\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib45\">2011</a>; Lehner et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib28\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib28\">2014</a>). In spite of these advances, numerous open questions remain regarding the physical nature of the absorbers themselves. Cosmological simulations predict that many of these systems arise in the environments of luminous galaxies, tracing cool inflowing streams or large-scale outflows driven by star formation (e.g., Fumagalli et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib19\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib19\">2011</a>; Shen et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib44\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib44\">2013</a>; Faucher-Gigu\u00e8re et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib16\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib16\">2015</a>). However, it has proven difficult to leverage such predictions for constraints on the physical origins of a given observed absorber population.</p><p>A crucial limitation has been our lack of information on the sizes and morphologies of the absorbing structures. Because background quasars provide only a pencil-beam probe, constraints on the physical extent of these systems have been obtained via modeling of the ionization state of the gas (Churchill &amp; Charlton <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib8\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib8\">1999</a>; Stocke et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib51\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib51\">2013</a>; Werk et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib53\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib53\">2014</a>). However, these analyses are subject to substantial systematic uncertainties (e.g., in the shape of the extragalactic ionizing background spectrum and in the cloud geometry/density profile), and typically may only be used to constrain the cloud thickness to within an order of magnitude (e.g., Werk et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib53\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib53\">2014</a>).</p><p>Spectroscopy of multiple, close background sight lines offers a valuable alternative probe of absorber morphology by mapping the transverse dimension. Gravitationally lensed quasars are perhaps the most efficient such sources, as they may be very bright and produce similar continua at a given <em>\u03bb</em><sub>obs</sub>. These unique sources have been used in numerous previous studies to probe the scale of variations in absorption strength (e.g., Smette et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib47\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib47\">1995</a>; Monier et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib32\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib32\">1998</a>; Rauch et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib38\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib38\">1999</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib39\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib39\">2001</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib40\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib40\">2002</a>; Ellison et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib15\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib15\">2004</a>). In particular, Ellison et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib15\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib15\">2004</a>) and Rogerson &amp; Hall (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib41\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib41\">2012</a>) have presented compilations of such measurements from the literature, and have used these data sets to constrain the coherence length of the absorbers under the assumption of spherical clouds (in the former) and in the context of the Tinker &amp; Chen (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib52\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib52\">2008</a>) gaseous halo model (in the latter). The Ellison et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib15\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib15\">2004</a>) analysis points to coherence lengths &gt;3 kpc for both highly ionized systems and for strong (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn132.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}</script></span></span>\u00a0&gt; 0.3 \u00c5) Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> systems, and suggests shorter coherence lengths for weaker low-ionization absorption systems. These findings are qualitatively consistent with the present analysis (which includes some of the same data along with a supplemental sample of lensed sight lines at separations &gt;5 kpc). Overall, the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn133.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}</script></span></span> variations observed in these systems indicate that either (1) each gas cloud composing the absorbers extends across the physical separation of the beams, or (2) they arise from extended structures made up of numerous smaller clouds with similar velocity spread and/or column density along any given sight line.</p><p>Ultimately, higher spectral resolution (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn134.gif\" alt=\"${ \\mathcal R }\\gt 6000$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{ \\mathcal R }\\gt 6000</script></span></span>) will be required to distinguish between these scenarios, as it permits detailed comparison of the column densities, velocity centroids, and line widths of individual absorbing components across the sight lines (e.g., Rauch et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib38\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib38\">1999</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib39\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib39\">2001</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib40\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib40\">2002</a>; Chen et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib6\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib6\">2014</a>). Indeed, such studies have already provided evidence for variation in velocity structure on sub-kiloparsec scales in the case of low-ionization absorption (e.g., Rauch et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib40\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib40\">2002</a>) and on scales of kiloparsecs in the case of high-ionization absorbers (e.g., Smette et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib47\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib47\">1995</a>; Rauch et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib39\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib39\">2001</a>). A spectroscopic survey for galaxies associated with these absorbers will allow us to establish their context within the CGM, and will, in addition, test a basic assumption invoked by most CGM studies to date. Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> absorbers with strengths similar to those in our sample (with <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn135.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}</script></span></span>\u00a0\u2248\u00a00.1\u20131 \u00c5) are common within projected distances of<em> R</em><sub>\u22a5</sub>\u00a0&lt;\u00a050 kpc of ~<em>L</em>* galaxies at low redshift (<em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a00.2; Chen et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib7\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib7\">2010</a>). However, constraints on the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn136.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}},2796}</script></span></span> distribution in these environments come from the assembly of numerous projected QSO-galaxy pairs, each of which probes an independent halo. Larger samples of lensed QSOs probing foreground systems (e.g., Chen et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib6\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib6\">2014</a>; Zahedy et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib58\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib58\">2016</a>) will provide a critical test of the standard interpretation that the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/859/2/146/Full/apjaaaeb7ieqn137.gif\" alt=\"${W}_{{\\rm{r}}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{W}_{{\\rm{r}}}</script></span></span> distribution of absorbers observed toward an ensemble of QSO-galaxy pairs is representative of the absorption profile in an individual galaxy CGM.</p><p>Moreover, measurement of the sizes, velocity coherence, and metallicity of such absorbers will permit quantitative comparisons to the CGM features predicted in hydrodynamical zoom simulations, differentiating between smooth accretion streams, gas associated with infalling satellites, and the turbulent, clumpy flows arising from stellar feedback (e.g., Shen et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib44\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib44\">2013</a>; Faucher-Gigu\u00e8re et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib16\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib16\">2015</a>; Nelson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib33\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib33\">2015</a>; Fielding et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib17\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib17\">2017</a>). Such constraints will, in addition, be necessary to assess the susceptibility of these structures to destruction by hydrodynamic instabilities, and hence will reveal their survival timescale (e.g., Crighton et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib11a\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib11a\">2015</a>; McCourt et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib31\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib31\">2018</a>). With &gt;2000 lensed QSOs expected to be discovered in the ongoing PS1 and Dark Energy Surveys (Dark Energy Survey Collaboration et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib13\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib13\">2016</a>), and several thousand to be uncovered by the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (Ivezic et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib23\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib23\">2008</a>; Oguri &amp; Marshall <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib34\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib34\">2010</a>), this technique will soon become the state of the art in CGM studies.</p></div> <div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>K.L.C. acknowledges support from NSF grant AST-1615296. The authors wish to thank Jessica Werk and Dylan Nelson for illuminating discussions of these results, and we thank Jessica Werk for her reading and critique of this manuscript. The data presented herein were obtained at the W.\u00a0M.\u00a0Keck Observatory, which is operated as a scientific partnership among the California Institute of Technology, the University of California, and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The Observatory was made possible by the generous financial support of the W.\u00a0M.\u00a0Keck Foundation.</p><p>The authors wish to recognize the very significant cultural role and reverence that the summit of Maunakea has always had within the indigenous Hawaiian community. We are most fortunate to have the opportunity to conduct observations from this mountain.</p><p>Finally, the authors dedicate this work to the memory of Jerry Nelson, without whom the immense contributions to science made by the Keck Observatory would not be possible.</p><p><em>Facility:</em> Keck:II (KCWI). - \n</p></div></div><!-- End article full text -->\n<!-- Start Footnotes -->\n\t<h2 id=\"footnotes\">Footnotes</h2>\n\t\t<div data-mobile-collapse=\"\">\n\t\t\t<ul class=\"clear-list wd-content-footnotes\">\n\t\t\t\t<li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"apjaaaeb7fn1\" id=\"apjaaaeb7fn1\">7\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><p class=\"mb-0\"><p>The NASA Apollo and Orion command modules and SpaceX Dragon capsule (source image D) made ocean landings with the aid of a parachute system (A\u2013C).</p></p></div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"apjaaaeb7fn2\" id=\"apjaaaeb7fn2\">8\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><p class=\"mb-0\"><p>We note a small offset of approximately 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />18 W and 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />22 N between the <em>Gaia</em> position listed for component D in Berghea et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7bib3\" id=\"fnref-apjaaaeb7bib3\">2017</a>) and the centroid of this source image in the PS1 imaging. We have adjusted the location of the symbol marking the lensing galaxy in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjaaaeb7f1\">1</a> accordingly.</p></p></div></li><li The data verify the source as a quadruply lensed, broad absorption-line quasar having {z}<SUB>{{S</SUB>}}=2.377 +/- 0.007. We detect intervening absorption in the Fe II \u03bb\u03bb2586, 2600, Mg II \u03bb\u03bb2796, 2803, and/or C IV \u03bb\u03bb1548, 1550 transitions in eight foreground systems, three of which have redshifts consistent with the photometric-redshift estimate reported for the lensing galaxy (z <SUB>L</SUB> \u2248 0.57). The source images probe these absorbers over transverse physical scales of \u22480.3-22 kpc, permitting assessment of the variation in metal-line equivalent width {W}<SUB>{{r</SUB>}} as a function of sight-line separation. We measure differences in {W}<SUB>{{r</SUB>},2796} of &lt;40% across most of the sight-line pairs subtending 8-22 kpc, suggestive of a high degree of spatial coherence for the Mg II-absorbing material. {W}<SUB>{{r</SUB>},2600} varies by &gt;50% over the same scales across the majority of sight-line pairs, while C IV absorption exhibits a wide range in {W}<SUB>{{r</SUB>},1548} differences of \u22485%-80% within transverse distances of \u22723 kpc. These spatial variations are consistent with those measured in intervening absorbers detected toward lensed quasars drawn from the literature, in which {W}<SUB>{{r</SUB>},2796} and {W}<SUB>{{r</SUB>},1548} vary by \u226420% in 35 \u00b1 7% and 47 \u00b1 6% of sight lines separated by &lt;10 kpc, respectively. J014710+463040 is one of only a handful of z &gt; 2 quadruply lensed systems for which all four source images are very bright (r = 15.4-17.7 mag) and are easily separated in ground-based seeing conditions. As such, it is an ideal candidate for higher-resolution spectroscopy probing the spatial variation in the kinematic structure and physical state of intervening absorbers.", "start_page": "146", "authors": ["Rubin, Kate H. R.", "O'Meara, John M.", "Cooksey, Kathy L.", "Matuszewski, Mateusz", "Rizzi, Luca", "Doppmann, Greg", "Kwok, Shui", "Martin, D. itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Periodical\">\n        <a name=\"\" id=\"skip-to-content-link-target\" tabindex=\"-1\"></a>\n        <div class=\"wrapper grid-3-col da-showgrid ta-showgrid cf\">\n    <main role=\"main\">\n        <!-- Secondary header starts -->\n<div class=\"secondary-header cf\" id=\"wd-secondary-header\">\n    <!-- Branded journal header starts -->\n<div class=\"big-branded\">\n\n    <div class=\"publication-name\" id=\"wd-pub-name\">\n\t<div class=\"publication-title\" itemprop=\"name\" itemid=\"periodical\">\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Journal image link tile starts -->\n<!-- Logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"/journal/0004-637X\" itemprop=\"url\">\n    <img src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8febf88b-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/apj-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Astrophysical Journal\">\n</a>\n<!-- Logo tile ends -->\n<!-- Journal image link tile ends -->\n</div>\n\t\t</div>\n    <div class=\"partner-logos m-hide\" id=\"wd-partner-logos\">\n            <div class=\"partner-logo-alignment\">\n                <!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The American Astronomical Society (AAS), established in 1899 and based in Washington, DC, is the major organization of professional astronomers in North America. Its membership of about 7,000 individuals also includes physicists, mathematicians, geologists, engineers, and others whose research and educational interests lie within the broad spectrum of subjects comprising contemporary astronomy. The mission of the AAS is to enhance and share humanity's scientific understanding of the universe.</p> <p><a href=\"https://aas.org/\">https://aas.org/</a></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The Institute of Physics (IOP) is a leading scientific society promoting physics and bringing physicists together for the benefit of all. It has a worldwide membership of around 50 000 comprising physicists from all sectors, as well as those with an interest in physics. It works to advance physics research, application and education; and engages with policy makers and the public to develop awareness and understanding of physics. Its publishing company, IOP Publishing, is a world leader in professional scientific communications.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.iop.org\">https://www.iop.org</a></p></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<p></p>\n                </div>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n<!-- Branded journal header ends -->\n</div> <!-- end secondary-header -->\n<!-- Secondary header ends --><div class=\"da1-da2\" itemscope=\"\" itemtype=\"http://schema.org/ScholarlyArticle\" id=\"page-content\">\n            <div class=\"da1 ta1 article-head\">\n                <!-- Start Eyebrow block, containing Surtitle and Labels -->\n<div class=\"eyebrow\">\n\t<!-- Start Collection Labels -->\n    <!-- End Collection Labels --> </div>\n<!-- End Eyebrow block -->\n\n<h1 itemprop=\"headline\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-title\">Andromeda's Parachute: A Bright Quadruply Lensed Quasar at <I>z</I>\u00a0=\u00a02.377</h1>\n\n<p class=\"mb-0\">\n\t<span data-authors=\"\">\n\t\t<span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">Kate H. R. Rubin</span><a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://orcid.org/0000-0001-6248-1864\" title=\"https://orcid.org/0000-0001-6248-1864\"><svg xmlns=\"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg\" viewBox=\"0 0 256 256\" width=\"20\" class=\"orcid-logo\"><path class=\"st0\" d=\"M256 128c0 70.7-57.3 128-128 128C57.3 256 0 198.7 0 128 0 57.3 57.3 0 128 0 198.7 0 256 57.3 256 128z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M86.3 186.2H70.9V79.1h15.4v48.4V186.2z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M108.9 79.1h41.6c39.6 0 57 28.3 57 53.6 0 27.5-21.5 53.6-56.8 53.6h-41.8V79.1zM124.3 172.4h24.5c34.9 0 42.9-26.5 42.9-39.7 0-21.5-13.7-39.7-43.7-39.7h-23.7V172.4z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M88.7 56.8c0 5.5-4.5 10.1-10.1 10.1 -5.6 0-10.1-4.6-10.1-10.1 0-5.6 4.5-10.1 10.1-10.1C84.2 46.7 88.7 51.3 88.7 56.8z\"></path></svg> https://orcid.org/0000-0001-6248-1864</a></span></p><p class=\"mb-05\"><span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">John M. O'Meara</span><a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7893-1054\" title=\"https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7893-1054\"><svg xmlns=\"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg\" viewBox=\"0 0 256 256\" width=\"20\" class=\"orcid-logo\"><path class=\"st0\" d=\"M256 128c0 70.7-57.3 128-128 128C57.3 256 0 198.7 0 128 0 57.3 57.3 0 128 0 198.7 0 256 57.3 256 128z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M86.3 186.2H70.9V79.1h15.4v48.4V186.2z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M108.9 79.1h41.6c39.6 0 57 28.3 57 53.6 0 27.5-21.5 53.6-56.8 53.6h-41.8V79.1zM124.3 172.4h24.5c34.9 0 42.9-26.5 42.9-39.7 0-21.5-13.7-39.7-43.7-39.7h-23.7V172.4z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M88.7 56.8c0 5.5-4.5 10.1-10.1 10.1 -5.6 0-10.1-4.6-10.1-10.1 0-5.6 4.5-10.1 10.1-10.1C84.2 46.7 88.7 51.3 88.7 56.8z\"></path></svg> https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7893-1054</a></span></p><p class=\"mb-05\"><span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">Luca Rizzi</span><a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://orcid.org/0000-0003-0882-2327\" title=\"https://orcid.org/0000-0003-0882-2327\"><svg xmlns=\"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg\" viewBox=\"0 0 256 256\" width=\"20\" class=\"orcid-logo\"><path class=\"st0\" d=\"M256 128c0 70.7-57.3 128-128 128C57.3 256 0 198.7 0 128 0 57.3 57.3 0 128 0 198.7 0 256 57.3 256 128z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M86.3 186.2H70.9V79.1h15.4v48.4V186.2z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M108.9 79.1h41.6c39.6 0 57 28.3 57 53.6 0 27.5-21.5 53.6-56.8 53.6h-41.8V79.1zM124.3 172.4h24.5c34.9 0 42.9-26.5 42.9-39.7 0-21.5-13.7-39.7-43.7-39.7h-23.7V172.4z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M88.7 56.8c0 5.5-4.5 10.1-10.1 10.1 -5.6 0-10.1-4.6-10.1-10.1 0-5.6 4.5-10.1 10.1-10.1C84.2 46.7 88.7 51.3 88.7 56.8z\"></path></svg> https://orcid.org/0000-0003-0882-2327</a></span></p><p class=\"mb-05\"><span itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Person\" itemprop=\"author\" class=\"nowrap\"><span itemprop=\"name\">James D. Neill</span><a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0466-1119\" title=\"https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0466-1119\"><svg xmlns=\"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg\" viewBox=\"0 0 256 256\" width=\"20\" class=\"orcid-logo\"><path class=\"st0\" d=\"M256 128c0 70.7-57.3 128-128 128C57.3 256 0 198.7 0 128 0 57.3 57.3 0 128 0 198.7 0 256 57.3 256 128z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M86.3 186.2H70.9V79.1h15.4v48.4V186.2z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M108.9 79.1h41.6c39.6 0 57 28.3 57 53.6 0 27.5-21.5 53.6-56.8 53.6h-41.8V79.1zM124.3 172.4h24.5c34.9 0 42.9-26.5 42.9-39.7 0-21.5-13.7-39.7-43.7-39.7h-23.7V172.4z\"></path><path class=\"st1\" d=\"M88.7 56.8c0 5.5-4.5 10.1-10.1 10.1 -5.6 0-10.1-4.6-10.1-10.1 0-5.6 4.5-10.1 10.1-10.1C84.2 46.7 88.7 51.3 88.7 56.8z\"></path></svg> https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0466-1119</a></span></p></div><!-- End ORCIDs --><!-- Start Dates -->\n<div class=\"col-no-break wd-jnl-art-dates\">\n        <div class=\"replica-h4\">Dates</div>\n        <p>\n            \n                Received <span itemprop=\"dateReceived\">2017 July 17</span><br />\n            \n                Accepted <span itemprop=\"dateAccepted\">2018 February 9</span><br />\n            \n                    Published <span itemprop=\"datePublished\">2018 June 1</span><br />\n                </p>\n    </div>\n<!-- End Dates -->\n\n<!-- Start Crossmark -->\n\t\t\t\t<p class=\"wd-jnl-art-crossmark\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<a target=\"_blank\" -->\n\n<!--  Start Citation -->\n                    <!--  End Citation -->\n\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Start DOI -->\n\t\t\t\t<div class=\"col-no-break wd-jnl-art-doi\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<div class=\"replica-h4\">\n\t\t\t\t\t<abbr title=\"digital object identifier\">DOI</abbr>\n\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\t<p><a itemprop=\"sameAs\" href=\"https://doi.org/10.3847/1538-4357/aaaeb7\">https://doi.org/10.3847/1538-4357/aaaeb7</a></p>\n\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t<!-- End DOI -->\n\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Start Accepted manuscript Link -->\n<!-- End Accepted manuscript Link -->\n<!-- Start Annotations -->\n <!-- End Annotations --><div class=\"col-no-break wd-jnl-aas-keywords\">\n\t\t<div class=\"replica-h4\">Keywords</div>\n\t\t<p><a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=2%2F46&amp;code_desc=gravitational+lensing%3A+strong\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>; <a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=11%2F21&amp;code_desc=intergalactic+medium\">intergalactic medium</a>; <a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=11%2F33&amp;code_desc=quasars%3A+absorption+lines\">quasars: absorption lines</a>; <a href=\"/searchaaskeyword?source=aas&amp;type=kwd_group&amp;code=3%2F34&amp;code_desc=techniques%3A+imaging+spectroscopy\">techniques: imaging spectroscopy</a></p>\n\t</div>\n<!-- Start Reprint Link -->\n\t<!-- End Reprint Link --><!-- Start Journal RSS feed -->\n                    <div class=\"jnl-notifications-wrapper jnl-notifications-wrapper--rss\">\n                        <a Journal RSS feed -->\n\t\t\t\t\t<!-- Start Email Alert -->\n    <!-- Start Email Alert -->\n        <div class=\"jnl-notifications-wrapper\">\n            <a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert
